records.paper_title: A Robust IoT Architecture for Real-Time Battery and Environmental Monitoring in Coal-Mine Infrastructure
records.abstract:
This paper presents the design and validation of an intelligent IoT-enabled architecture for integrated battery and
environmental health monitoring in coal-mine Wi-Fi towers. The proposed system combines voltage and environmental sensing
with both cloud and local interfaces to ensure data visibility and resilience under connectivity disruptions. Three hardware prototypes were iteratively developed to balance cost, sustainability, and industrial durability, using modular sensor integration and robust enclosures. Experimental evaluation on a lab-grade battery confirmed stable voltage tracking and reliable temperature, humidity, pressure, and air-quality measurements. A real-time web dashboard enables visualization, alerting, and geolocation-based monitoring of distributed units. The results demonstrate a dependable, low-cost platform suitable for deployment in harsh field environments. Future extensions will focus on large-scale field validation, predictive analytics for battery health estimation, and enhanced communication redundancy for industrial-scale energy monitoring.

records.paper_title: Magnetic Characterization and an Arctan-based Multi-Component Nonlinear Modelling of Mangifera Indica L. Tissues for PBC Applications
records.abstract: The growing global population and rising food demand, coupled with environmental challenges, call for advanced agricultural technologies. Plant Body Communication (PBC) is an emerging approach that utilizes intrinsic plant tissues for signal transmission, enabling seamless integration of plant sensors via a unified gateway for real-time monitoring and controlled magnetic and/or electric stimuli across growth stages. Realizing PBC requires precise characterization of the electrical and magnetic properties of plant tissues. In this work, the M - H characteristics of different types of Mangifera indica L. tissues were measured across different seasons using a vibrating sample magnetometer under magnetic fields up to 1.8 ×104 Oe at room temperature. The measured data were analyzed using an arctan-based multi-component nonlinear model, with parameters extracted via nonlinear least-squares optimization, capturing seasonal and tissue-specific variations. The reliability of the extracted magnetic parameters was validated using the coefficient of determination (R2). These findings provide new insights into plant-based biomagnetism and support the development of robust PBC systems (for continuous monitoring and nutrient diagnostics) in precision agriculture.

records.paper_title: Smart Scale
records.abstract: Precise nutritional monitoring remains challenging despite advances in mobile health applications. Existing image-only approaches struggle with visually similar foods and hidden ingredients, limiting their reliability for users requiring accurate dietary data. Smart Scale introduces a novel multi-modal approach, integrating precision weighing technology with artificial intelligence-powered visual recognition. The system combines embedded sensors, uniform illumination, and cloud-based deep learning to provide comprehensive nutritional analysis. Validation studies confirmed substantial improvements in user experience, logging efficiency, and estimation accuracy compared to conventional methods, establishing Smart Scale as a practical solution for automated dietary monitoring.

records.paper_title: A Lightweight CNN Framework with SAM-Based Preprocessing for Luffa Disease Detection
records.abstract:
The accurate and automatic detection of diseases in Luffa is crucial for safeguarding crop yield. While deep learning offers promising solutions, many models suffer from
high computational complexity. This paper introduces a robust and efficient pipeline for automated identification of Luffa leaf diseases. It consists of the Segment Anything Model (SAM)-based image preprocessing and a lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The use of a zero-shot segmentation tool, such as SAM, helps the proposed pipeline isolate the leaf from the background and enhance the performance of the CNN. The proposed CNN combines modified MBConv blocks with a dual-branch Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) mechanism, achieving a remarkably small footprint of just 166K parameters, 204.5 MMac FLOPs, and 0.58 MB of memory footprint. Evaluated
on the benchmark LuffaFolio dataset, our method demonstrates that SAM-based preprocessing improves accuracy by 19.73% and F1-score by 20.98% compared to using the original images. The result demonstrates the critical role of advanced segmentation in achieving robust classification. Also, the proposed CNN is optimal for deployment on low-powered edge and TinyML devices. In summary, the proposed framework provides a practical solution for in-field plant disease diagnosis, enabling timely intervention to minimize crop yield losses.

records.paper_title: A Disposable Sensor Combined with LDA-SVM for Rapid Detection of Milk Fat Percentage and Water Adulteration
records.abstract:
This paper presents milk adulteration, particularly
through dilution with water, poses a serious concern for consumer
safety and product integrity. This study presents a impedance based
disposable paper sensor which requires only 0.4ml milk (i.e
a drop of milk) to asses the identification of milk fat content
and detection of water adulteration using machine learning
framework. Impedance magnitude(|Z|)data, recorded over 20Hz-
1MHz,were analysed using Linear Discriminant Analysis(LDA)
to reduce dimensionality. The extracted discriminant features
were further classified using Support Vector Machine(SVM) with
a medium Gaussian kernel. The proposed LDA-SVM model
achieved accuracies of 95.3% for water adultered milk and
81.7% for distinguishing between fat percentage of milk. This
result demonstrate that combining impedance spectroscopy with
data driven classification offers a reliable approach for milk
quality monitoring, enabling on-site adulteration detection and
composition analysis.

records.paper_title: In-Vitro and In-Vivo EIS-Based Analysis and Validation of Salt Stress Response in Pusa Basmati 1 Rice
records.abstract: Rice is one of the most important food crops, serving as a major carbohydrate source worldwide. With ongoing climatic changes, abiotic stress has emerged as a critical challenge to rice production. Among these, salinity stress caused by excess salt in soil significantly impacts rice growth, particularly during germination and reproductive stages. To address the need for a cost-effective analytical approach, we evaluated salt stress in Pusa Basmati 1 rice plants using in vivo and in vitro electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). In addition, morphological changes, such as reduced plant height, leaf dimensions, shoot thickness, and root development, were recorded under increasing salt concentrations. EIS data, interpreted using an equivalent circuit model, revealed systematic variations in impedance and admittance parameters correlating with salt-induced morphological alterations.

records.paper_title: Graphene/PEDOT:PSS Hybrid Ink Based Flexible and Eco-Friendly Humidity Sensor for Early Plant Leaf Stress Monitoring
records.abstract: In this work, we present a flexible and eco-friendly humidity sensor suitable for early plant leaf stress monitoring. The humidity sensor was fabricated using graphene/PEDOT:PSS hybrid ink deposited via drop-casting method on interdigitated electrodes (IDEs) screen printed on a eco-friendly paper substrate. Contact angle measurement, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) studies were performed to demonstrate hydrophilic nature, surface morphology and elemental analysis, respectively, of the sensing layer. The sensor exhibited excellent sensing performance in the measured relative humidity (%RH) range from 25% RH to 94% RH having a maximum % response of 226.5%. The sensor demonstrated a nearly linear response (adj. R² = 0.99) in the considered range with a slope observed as 3.21 %/%RH. Multi-cyclic repeatability and reproducibility analysis further confirmed high reliability and consistent performance of the developed sensor. Furthermore, the capability of the sensor was successfully evaluated through capturing variations in plant physiological health status (under different environmental conditions, such as un-watered, water availability and solar irradiation) via monitoring microclimatic relative humidity (%RH) variations on plant (Epiremnun aureum) leaves. Through establishing the %RH values for healthy crops or plants under normal (well-watered) and stress conditions (un-watered or excessive solar irradiations), sensor seems to demonstrate strong potential for smart agriculture i.e., detecting early plant leaf stress.

records.paper_title: Quality Assessment and Valuation of Made-Tea Using ROI Segmentation and Spectral–TDS Fusion
records.abstract:
Consistent and objective valuation of made-tea is critical for quality control and pricing in the tea industry; however, conventional manual tasting is subjective, fatigue-prone, and difficult to scale. In addition, the visually complex nature of made-tea—characterized by curled and broken particles, overlapping structures, shadows, and non-uniform backgrounds—poses significant challenges for reliable image-based analysis.
 
This work presents a fully automated, operator-independent system for made-tea quality assessment by fusing region-of-interest (ROI) segmentation from spectral imaging with Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) measurements. A robust ROI isolation pipeline is developed using adaptive two-stage K-means segmentation, boundary-confidence filtering, and automated non-overlapping bounding-box extraction to mitigate segmentation-driven noise. Spectral reflectance features extracted from isolated ROIs are fused with TDS values to capture both physical and chemical characteristics of tea samples.
 
The proposed approach predicts the two-digit Valuation Grade (VG; Body–Zing: 0–5 each) and achieves an accuracy of 95.2% on an independent test set, with significant improvement in signal-to-noise ratio (+12.4 dB) and reduction in contamination (from 14.6% to 0.9%). The system demonstrates high repeatability (r = 0.97) and rapid processing (402 ms per sample), making it suitable for industrial deployment.
 
Overall, the proposed spectral–TDS fusion framework enables fast, reliable, and scalable made-tea valuation, offering a practical alternative to subjective manual grading in quality-control workflows.

records.paper_title: FFT and Chirp-Z Transform Based Signal Processing for Precision FMCW RADAR Level Measurement
records.abstract:
This paper investigates signal processing strategies for a 24 GHz FMCW RADAR-based level measurement system in harsh environments. Range estimation depends on accurate determination of the intermediate frequency (IF) generated by the beat signal. Conventional Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) method is limited by frequency bin width, reducing sensitivity to small displacements. A Chirp-Z Transform (CZT) based approach was implemented to improve spectral resolution. Experiments with in-house developed horn antennas and an ADF5901/5904 transceiver module demonstrated that while FFT outputs remained constant for 1 cm
displacements, the CZT method successfully resolved them. Nonlinear estimation trends were attributed to the nonlinearity of the oscillator control voltage. The study highlights CZT as a promising tool for high-resolution RADAR sensing, with future work aimed at calibration and linearization.

records.paper_title: Physics Inspired Approach for Enhancing Underwater Images using Virtual Polarizer
records.abstract: Underwater image enhancement is a challenge due to the absorption and scattering of light, which results in severe color distortion and hazy images that reduce contrast. In recent years, researchers have explored a variety of image-processing approaches such as illumination compensation and pyramid-based blending, CLAHE-based intensification filters, color balance combined with edge sharpening, and improved white balance algorithms to restore visibility in underwater environments. Building on these works, in this study we develop a novel variant of the polarization technique, clubbed with existing models like CLAHE, white balancing, and sharpening, to achieve better image quality. The proposed method, termed the virtual polarizer dehazing algorithm, employs a physics-backed model using pure image processing to deliver robust and visually consistent results. Experimental evaluations on benchmark datasets such as UIEB and EUPV demonstrate that our approach provides considerable improvements over conventional methods in both qualitative and quantitative metrics.

records.paper_title: Design and Simulation of a MEMS based Non-thermal Hair type Airflow Sensor
records.abstract: MEMS based non-thermal airflow sensors have recently emerged as a promising research area, offering high precision and accuracy for airflow measurements. This study introduces an airflow sensor inspired by the motion of human hair, presenting an innovative approach to enhance flow sensing capabilities. This sensor allows for precise measurement of airflow speeds within the laminar flow range. Additionally, the sensor’s deflection causes a change in resistance in piezo-resistive elements, leading to a voltage difference. The proposed sensor is designed for airflow velocities up to 40 m/s. A simulation based approach was employed to validate the sensor design, ensuring functionality under diverse flow conditions and contributing to significant advancements in airflow sensing technologies.

co_author.name: K. K. D. V. N. Kannangara

records.paper_title: Nanotechnology-Assisted Sensing and Remediation of Methylene Blue in Water
records.abstract: The presence of synthetic dyes in water is critical due to their persistence and toxicity, encouraging the development of effective methods for their detection, quantification and removal. In this work, silver nanoparticles were applied in a multi-purpose approach: detection, quantification and remediation of methylene blue in water. Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering of colloidal silver nanoparticles, enables reliable detection and quantification of methylene blue, with a limit of detection of 5x10−9 M. A cellulose-silver nanoparticle composite prepared from peanut husks provides methylene blue remediation. The removal efficiency of 99.9 % was achieved using 0.1 g of the adsorbent composite and 25 mL of a 10 −5 M methylene blue solution, whereas pure cellulose reached 97.6 % under the same conditions. This study highlights the potential of silver nanoparticles platforms as powerful analytical tools for environmental monitoring, while also supporting the development of sustainable remediation strategies.

records.paper_title: 3D printed automated optical delay stage with gear reduction enabled sub-micron microstepping
records.abstract: We demonstrate a novel 3D printed optical delay stage providing sub-micron level displacements. The delay stage actuation is based on lead-screw mechanism, and can be controlled using a conventional stepper motor. A key aspect of the design is the use of a fully 3D printed cascaded compound train gearbox, which provides different step sizes down to the submicron level without the need for microstepping control of the stepper motor. We demonstrate the delay stage performance using knife-edge based laser beamwidth measurements, which serve to underscore the precision and repeatability of the 3D printed stage and gearbox. The low complexity of realization, together with automation readiness and on-the-fly step-size adjustment makes our demonstrated design highly desirable for applications that require flexible optical delay control.

records.paper_title: High Precision Direct Detection-Based Automated Measurements of the Verdet Constant Using 3D Printing Technologies
records.abstract:
Magneto-optic materials are used for several applications, ranging from optical telecommunications to current sensing devices. High precision measurements of the associated Verdet constant is thus imperative to ensure the targeted performance for such applications. Typically this requires the use of advanced measurement configurations like balanced detection or multipass arrangements, which increases complexity of realization and associated costs. Here, we report high precision measurements of the Verdet constant obtained using a highly
simplified configuration employing off-the-shelf electronics and 3D printing. Specifically, we show that by a combination of direct detection and linear regression analysis, it is possible to achieve measurement precisions that are typically provided by lock-in approaches. The use of longer averaging windows enables enhanced precision, positioning the method as an effective and reliable solution for high-precision measurements in quasi-static regimes. This opens up opportunities not only for industry but also makes such precision measurements accessible for academic research and teaching.

records.paper_title: Multi-View Panoramic Thermal Infrared Monitoring with Edge Analytics for Resource-Constrained Sensing
records.abstract: Continuous monitoring of wide areas is pivotal for surveillance, environmental assessment, autonomous navigation, and industrial inspection. However, traditional wide-field-of-view (WFoV) lenses introduce geometric distortion, reduced angular resolution, and limited detection range. Multi-camera arrays and panoramic optics further increase system size, calibration complexity, and power demand, and often lack support for on-device computer-vision analytics in resource-constrained platforms. This paper introduces a compact, low-SWaP, and edge-deployable panoramic imaging system that uses a single narrow-field-of-view (NFoV) thermal camera mounted on a servo mechanism. By stepping the camera in discrete θFoV increments, the system synthesises a rectilinear panorama without overlap, blending, or geometric warping. A deterministic frame-gating strategy mitigates motion-induced blur by discarding k unstable frames until servo settling completes, ensuring spatial consistency. The resultant panoramic strip preserves native sensor resolution while expanding coverage beyond conventional WFoV lenses, enabling reliable on-board analytics. We demonstrate the system using an NFoV long-wave infrared sensor with an 18° horizontal field of view, achieving a 198° sweep composed of 11 segments processed directly on a Jetson Nano edge device. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and repeatability of the approach for real-time, resource-constrained wide-area thermal monitoring.

records.paper_title: Novel Al2O3/GO nanocomposite-based highly sensitive optical fiber humidity sensor
records.abstract: This research aims to develop simple and novel optical fiber relative humidity (RH) sensor that employs intensity modulation via evanescent wave (EW) absorption. Proposed sensor exploits Al₂O₃/GO nanocomposite doped thin film of nanostructured silica as the sensing cladding on a centrally decladded plastic-clad silica (PCS) fiber. This configuration is used for the first time to the best of author’s knowledge for the development of optical fiber RH sensor. Comprehensive experimental investigations are carried out to establish response characteristics of the sensor. Proposed sensor demonstrates a significantly enhanced sensitivity of 0.0107 RH⁻¹ while responding linearly over a dynamic range of 14%-86% RH. In addition, fast response/recovery time, excellent reversibility, repeatability, and reliability characteristics of the sensor make it suitable for real-field applications.

records.paper_title: Design and Optimization of Ni-Cr Microheaters Structures with Thickness Variation for Low- Power Operation
records.abstract: This study presents the design, fabrication, and characterization of four Ni-Cr microheater structures, incorporating variations in heater strip width (inner side wider than the outer side) and film thickness of 100, 200, and 300nm, each integrated with a temperature sensor for precise thermal monitoring. All fabricated microheaters exhibited nearly identical TCR values, with an average of 0.000260/°C. Among them, the 100 nm-thick microheater (Design 1) showed the lowest TCR of 0.000245/°C. Its integrated temperature sensor demonstrated a sensitivity of 1.33 Ω/°C, indicating good thermal response. Experimental analyses confirmed that thinner microheaters significantly reduce power consumption without compromising performance. Integration of the microheater platform with an Arduino Uno based PID controller achieved highly accurate temperature regulation, maintaining errors within ±8% and ensuring excellent temperature tracking. The developed system thus offers a robust solution for stable and controlled microscale heating, with promising implications for applications such as gas sensing and other scenarios demanding precise thermal management.

co_author.name: Bhawna Pareek
co_author.affiliation: Mody University of Science and Technology  Laxmangarh,

records.paper_title: Design of Reconfigurable Radar Signal Processor for Frequency-Modulated Continuous Wave Radar
records.abstract: This paper presents a reconfigurable radar signal processor with configurable FFT and CFAR IPs. The FFT IP supports FFT sizes from 64 to 4096 points. The CFAR IP supports CA, OS, SOOS, and GOOS algorithms.

records.paper_title: Optimization of Low-Noise Amplifier Circuits for Enhanced Sensor Signal Integrity
records.abstract: A Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) acts as an important component in sensor system design for wireless sensing applications. In this direction, this paper demonstrates a novel approach to optimizing LNA design using Grey Relation Analysis (GRA), a multi-objective optimization method. This technique was used to increase gain (S21), and stability factor (K), and decrease input reflection coefficient (S11), reverse voltage gain (S12), output reflection coefficient (S22), and Noise Figure (NF) for the LNA circuit. The LNA circuit was simulated in the Advanced Design System (ADS) tool. The obtained optimized input values are R3 = 665 Ω, R4= 12 Ω, L3 = 2 nH, C4 = 1.2 pF, C5 = 1.2 pF. In this situation, outputs had magnitudes as S11= -14.007 dB, S22= -17.023 dB, S12= -17.752 dB, S21= 11.390 dB, K = 1.210, NF= 0.882 dB at 4 GHz. Furthermore, an analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed to determine the impact of inputs on LNA outputs. This study suggests that the contribution of L3 is significantly high, with 98.62%.

records.paper_title: Spectral Line Enhancement for Noise-Resilient Passive Sonar Detection using Dual-Attention Guided Wavelet domain FISTA-Net
records.abstract:
Robust detection of underwater targets by passive sonar is hindered by weak tonal emissions masked by strong ambient noise in the marine environment. These narrowband components, represented as spectral lines in the LOFAR spectrum of received acoustic signals, are critical for target recognition but remain difficult to enhance under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. We propose a spectral enhancement framework that combines a frequency domain adaptive line enhancer (ALE) with a dual-attention guided wavelet domain fast iterative shrinkage thresholding algorithm network (FISTA-Net). The ALE stage suppresses broadband noise while preserving spectral structures, whereas wavelet domain FISTA employs multiresolution analysis and attention-guided weighting to enhance weak spectral features under sparsity constraints. Experimental results show an average SNR improvement of 4.87 dB over block-processed sparsity-
based on ALE and 6.37 dB over conventional ALE. To further study the recognition accuracy of the proposed method, a common ResNet based classifier is used. The proposed method outperforms existing approaches, achieving higher classification accuracy and demonstrating its effectiveness for underwater target detection and recognition.

records.paper_title: Wet Bulk Micromachining of Si{110} with IPA-added NH4OH Etchant for MEMS-based Sensor Application
records.abstract: This study investigates the wet anisotropic etching behavior of Si{110} wafers in ammonium hydroxide (NH₄OH), with and without the addition of isopropyl alcohol (IPA), as etchants for MEMS applications involving the formation of various microstructures. A SiO2 thin film is employed as the masking layer, and photolithography is used to transfer microstructure patterns onto the SiO2. The concentration of IPA is varied incrementally from 2% to 20%, while the NH₄OH concentration remains fixed at 70 °C. The study reveals that pure NH₄OH yields high etch rates, pronounced undercutting at convex corners, and increased surface roughness. In contrast, the incorporation of IPA significantly suppresses these effects, leading to smoother etched surfaces and enhanced dimensional control. These findings demonstrate the potential of IPA-added NH₄OH solutions as effective etchants for accurately fabricating microstructures with smooth surfaces, making them well-suited to a range of MEMS-based sensor applications.

records.paper_title: An IoT-Integrated IMU Sensor Node for Affordable Crash Detection and Emergency Notification
records.abstract: A low-cost crash detection and emergency alert system using an IMU, ESP32-C3, and smartphone is presented. Crash detection is local, while GPS and SMS alerts are handled by the phone to reduce cost and improve portability.
records.affiliation: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India

co_author.name: S. G. Ganpule
co_author.affiliation: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India

records.paper_title: Enhancing Electric Vehicle Route Transparency Using Explainable AI Integrated Quantum Deep Reinforcement Learning framework for Green Transportation
records.abstract: The rapid adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has intensified the demand for intelligent routing systems capable of minimizing travel time, reducing energy consumption, and ensuring reliable access to charging infrastructure. Conventional routing algorithms often fail to incorporate dynamic, real-world constraints such as traffic fluctuations, charger availability, environmental conditions, and the nonlinear nature of EV energy usage. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a Quantum-Enhanced Deep Reinforcement Learning Transformer framework integrated with explainable AI for efficient EV routing across the Delhi–NCR megaregion. The model combines quantum-inspired optimization, deep neural policy networks, and real geospatial charging-station data, enriched with live weather intelligence to accurately estimate energy demand. Experimental evaluation shows that the proposed Q-DRL policy achieves an average energy savings of 1.5171 kWh per trip, equivalent to a 12.04% improvement compared to a baseline approach, highlighting the model’s ability to generate energy-optimal, trustworthy routes. This study provides a scalable, data-driven foundation for next-generation EV mobility, supporting smarter and cleaner urban transportation.

records.paper_title: Differential Self-Attention in 1D CNNs for Driver Inattention Detection Using Multimodal Biosignals
records.abstract: Driver inattention detection is crucial for road safety, as stress can impair cognitive functions and increase accident risk. Recent advances in wearable technology have led to an increase in the use of multimodal physiological signals for driver inattention detection. Integrating attention mechanisms into these systems has shown promise in enhancing inattention detection. However, attention features can be affected by noise in the data, presenting a significant challenge. To address this, we propose a multimodal Differential Self-Attention based 1D Convolutional Neural Network (MDSA-1DCNN) to reduce noise in attention features. In this study, we evaluate the effectiveness of MDSA-1DCNN on multimodal 1D biosignals obtained from textile electrodes, collecting single-lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) (256 Hz) and Respiration (RSP) (128 Hz) data from 15 healthy participants in two driving states: Normal and inattention.  The raw data were divided into non-overlapping segments of 10, 15, and 20 seconds and preprocessed using the Neurokit Toolbox. These processed segments from each modality were then passed through convolutional blocks to extract temporal features. Self-attention was applied to these features, followed by a differential attention layer to reduce noise. The resulting features were fed into dense layers to classify driver inattention state. The proposed MDSA-1DCNN approach achieved a weighted F-Score of 73.23 % and an average accuracy of 78.51 % on the validation set using Leave-One-Subject-Out Cross-Validation. Future work will explore the utilization of data from multiple sensors and investigate sensor fusion techniques.

records.paper_title: A Novel Multilayer Functional Brain Connectivity-Based Motor Imagery Classification Model Using EEG Sensor Data
records.abstract:
This letter presents a novel electroencephalography (EEG) rhythm-based motor imagery (MI) classification
framework employing multilayer weighted visibility graph (WVG) and deep learning. In this study, multi-channel EEG
signals corresponding to different MI classes were acquired from various subjects by placing sensors on the scalp. The
acquired EEG signals were initially decomposed into five frequency sub-bands (EEG rhythms), by segmenting into 2-
second overlapping windows. For each rhythm, a multi-layer functional brain network (FBN) has been constructed
utilizing WVG, and the resulting functional brain connectivity matrices (FBC) were mapped into RGB images, which were
further classified through a lightweight custom ConvNeXt model. In this work, subject independent evaluation was
performed using a leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) protocol with stratified 10-fold cross-validation. Experimental validation
on two datasets- BCI Competition IV-2a and High Gamma Dataset (HGD), yielded accuracies of 90.20% and 96.1%,
respectively. The analysis reveals physiological meaningful connectivity patterns such as contralateral β-band
connectivity in BCI IV-2a and enhanced inter-hemispheric γ-band integration in HGD. Ablation studies and benchmark
comparison confirmed that the proposed framework achieved high classification accuracy, demonstrating the efficiency
and potential for robust, real-time subject-independent MI–BCI applications.

records.paper_title: Precision-Driven AI Smartphone-Based Sensor System for Fingernail-Based Non-Invasive Disease Detection
records.abstract: Liver disease and nail psoriasis can manifest through secondary nail changes, yet conventional diagnostic methods such as blood tests and biopsies remain invasive, costly, and painful for patients, highlighting the need for more accessible, non-invasive alternatives. This research introduces a novel deep learning (DL) based approach for the non-invasive detection of these diseases using fingernail image analysis.  Various DL models, including Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), VGG16, MobileNet, MobileNetV2, and InceptionV3, were evaluated, and accuracy of 82.66%, 91.33%, 90.00%, 90.67%, and 95.71% respectively for each model was achieved.  The models were trained on a dataset of fingernail images, and their performance was assessed based on classification accuracy. The accuracy of InceptionV3 achieved was the highest. Building upon this model's success, a mobile application integrated with sensor-based functionality was developed allowing users to upload fingernail images and receive instant diagnostic feedback conveniently enabling early detection. This research demonstrates the transformative potential of DL and sensor technology in healthcare by providing a fast, reliable, and non-invasive diagnostic tool for early diagnosing liver and nail psoriasis disease in clinical and remote applications.

records.paper_title: Dual-Mode Optical Detection of Cobalt Ions using Silica Nanoparticles
records.abstract: A facile one-pot synthesis of amine-functionalized silica nanoparticles (SiNPs) using 3-Aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) and basic fuchsin dye was developed to detect cobalt ions in an aqueous medium. The dual-mode sensing offers colorimetric and fluorescence response, enabling visual and quantitative detection. The quenching of fluorescence of SiNPs by cobalt is caused by the formation of the metal-ligand Co–NH₂ complex. A straightforward centrifugation step was used to achieve the purification of nanoparticles. These synthesized SiNPs were of average diameter ~270 nm and were able to detect cobalt through fluorescence quenching and colour change. This approach has a measurable detection limit of 0.30 μM Co2⁺ and a calculated detection limit of 0.27 μM Co2⁺ for fluorescence response, which is less than the US Environmental Protection Agency's maximum permitted cobalt concentration in water (1.7 μM). Also, static quenching is indicated since UV-Vis absorption spectrum of quencher (cobalt) and fluorescence spectrum of fluorophore (SiNPs) do not overlap. The straightforward, cost-effective synthesis and reliable optical response demonstrate the potential of this system for practical environmental cobalt monitoring applications.

records.paper_title: Low Level Detection of CH3OH Sensing  via MoS_2  /PANI Heterojunction Transistor
records.abstract:
The proposed article analyzes the sensing performance of molybdenum disulfide (M oS2) and polyaniline (PANI) heterostructure for methanol (CH3OH) gas at room temperature
through the evaluation of charge transfer and adsorption energy. In this article, density function theory (DFT) is utilized to calculate the charge transfer and adsorption energy for a single molecule. This has been further scaled up and utilized in the proposed thin-film transistor (TFT) based sensor. Due to the corresponding charge transfer, variation in different electrical parameters such as drain current (ID ), transconductance (gm), and mobility (μ) is recorded as a sensing parameter. The proposed sensor is tested for 1 ppb CH3OH, and it is the lowest detection limit reported to date, to the best of the authors’ knowledge. Sensitivity of the proposed sensor is recorded as 3.48 %,3.96%, 3.76 %, and 4.8 % for output transconductance(gd), μ, gm and ID , respectively. With the extremely low limit of detection (LOD), the proposed sensor can be utilized in various real-time applications such as environmental monitoring, health-care

records.paper_title: Design and Analysis of High-Resolution Airborne SAR Sensor at X Band Using LFM for Remote Sensing Applications
records.abstract: This study describes the design and analysis of a 16x16 antenna arrays for high resolution airborne synthetic aperture radar sensor at X-band with a linear frequency modulated waveform for advanced remote sensing applications. The suggested SAR system is designed for deployment on lightweight aerial platforms such as UAVs and small aircraft, allowing for high-resolution imaging in all weather and day night settings. The antenna array elements dimensions are 7.2x7.2 mm2 width and length with a height of 1.6mm roger 5880 substrate and the antenna arrays spacing of 0.5. The system uses a 600MHz LFM pulse for sub meter range resolution and Doppler-based azimuth compression for precise spatial accuracy. The system design consists of a compact high-gain antenna array, effective pulse compression techniques, and motion-compensated SAR imaging algorithms. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations and MATLAB-based signal processing validate the radar's capabilities, the reflection coefficient S11 at 12 GHz is -32 dB with a high gain of 33.79 dBi, this revealing strong picture generation with low sidelobe levels and a high signal to clutter ratio. The proposed design has applications in environmental monitoring, disaster assessment, and tactical reconnaissance.

records.paper_title: A Study on Remote Sensing and Smart Sensors for Urban Air Quality and Carbon Footprint Management
records.abstract: There is a need of effective strategies permitting feasible spatiotemporal monitoring and enabling actionable measures for urban air management through simulacrum and aerological gauge use (and similar). Although Continuous Ambient Air Quality Monitoring Stations (CAAQMS) data produced by Chemical Analytical methods are very accurate, they are limited due to limited spatial coverage and high cost. In this paper, we present a quantitative case-based assessment of Indore, India to show how a layered monitoring framework incorporating reference-grade stations, low-cost optical sensors and governance-driven analytics, combined with more general urban. Air quality parameters which are For 6 months, PM2.5, PM10, and Air Quality Index (AQI) was studied from traffic and residential sites.  The low-cost sensor data was calibrated with the help of co-located data from CAAQMS using Pearson correlation, Root mean square error, and mean absolute error for checking accuracy and reliability of low-cost sensors. The study used a descriptive analysis and one-way ANOVA of frequent samples to characterize and analyze the particulate matter. The findings reveal a strong statistical relationship between the calibrated low-cost sensors and the reference stations. Also, there was a noticeable difference in the spatial variation and seasonal behaviour. The high-traffic corridors had witnessed the persistent hotspots more. Sensors placed in highly populated regions recorded large outputs. The sensor-based governance model can potentially be employed at scale and be translated to other contexts but requires adequate.

records.paper_title: Label-Free Electrochemical Detection of Acetaminophen Using a Gold Nanoparticle–Modified Stainless Steel Electrode
records.abstract: Acetaminophen (AAP), also known as paracetamol, is a widely used ’over-the-counter’ medicine and one of the leading causes of soil and water contamination worldwide. The improper disposal of pharmaceutical residues during their production and from households poses a serious threat to aquatic systems and the environment. Hence, the development of simple, cost-effective, and reliable methods for AAP detection is of great importance for both health and environmental monitoring. In this work, we report the fabrication and characterization of an inexpensive label-free sensor for AAP detection based on AuNPs electrodeposited onto a stainless steel substrate. The electrochemical response of AAP by the Au-modified electrode exhibited well-defined redox peaks in cyclic voltammetry. Under optimized conditions (pH 5.96 in 0.1 M KH2PO4), the sensor demonstrated a dual detection behavior: a linear response in the low concentration range (0.8 μM to 0.03 mM) with a sensitivity of 2.08 mA mM−1 and a sigmoidal response in the higher concentration range (0.03-6.65 mM) with a sensitivity of 0.97 mA mM−1. The limit of detection (LOD) in the linear range was calculated to be 0.8 μM. The low-cost fabrication and promising performance of the fabricated sensor highlight its potential for integration into portable devices to monitor AAP contamination in water.

records.paper_title: Large-scale fabrication of fully printed, photoactivated Au decorated Tin Oxide based room-temperature NO2 sensors with ultra-high response on paper substrates
records.abstract: Conventional metal oxide gas sensors require high-temperature operation (200-300°C), which limits integration with sustainable and biodegradable substrates and contributes to electronic waste. Herein, we demonstrate fully screen printed, room-temperature NO₂ sensors using UV-photoactivated Au decorated SnO/SnO₂ nanoparticles on paper. Tin oxide nanoparticles have been synthesized via precipitation and annealing, followed by controlled Au decoration (0.5 wt.%) through ascorbic acid reduction. Subsequently, screen printing enables scalable device fabrication with interdigitated Ag electrodes and Au-SnO/SnO₂ sensing layers on photo paper. Under 365 nm UV illumination (2.1 mW/cm²), the sensors have exhibited excellent response of 871 for 3.2 ppm NO₂, at room temperature. The devices demonstrated remarkable sensitivity across 1.4-3.2 ppm level. Response and recovery times have been 225 s and 1020 s, respectively. Excellent selectivity has been achieved with 175% response to NO₂ versus 17% for Cl₂ and negligible response to NH₃. Successful integration into a portable USB-powered module has been demonstrated to showcase practical deployment capability. This approach offers a sustainable, scalable route for room-temperature gas sensing suitable for environmental and occupational health monitoring.

records.paper_title: Analysis of Mxene and Mxene/ZnO Composite based I-V Sensing for Antibiotic Detection
records.abstract:
The increasing presence of antibiotic pollutants, particularly
sulfamethoxazole (SMX), in water sources necessitates the
development of highly sensitive and selective detection methods.
In this study, the presented work is a current versus voltage (I-V)
sensor based on MXene/zinc oxide (ZnO) composite, which outperforms
MXene in detecting SMX with sensitivity. The sensor is
fabricated by spin-coating MXene, ZnO, and ZnO-MXene composite
films onto a flexible polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate
with an integrated conductive layer. The electrical response of the
device is analyzed using I-V characterization under varying SMX concentrations, demonstrating that pristine. The
sensitivity of MXene/ZnO composite 1.44×10-5 A/μg is attained by the compositing MXene and ZnO, which increases
11 times to the pure Mxene’s sensitivity 1.29×10-6 A/μg. This is achieved by the active site created
by ZnO on the MXene sheets. The results highlight MXene/ZnO composite potential as a next-generation material
for sensing applications, providing a promising alternative for real-time and on-site water quality monitoring.

records.paper_title: Comparative Chemiluminescence Sensing of Hydrogen Peroxide Using a Miniaturized Chip using Cobalt Catalyst versus Electrogenerated Emission at a Graphite Electrode
records.abstract: Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is a critical biomarker involved in oxidative stress and enzymatic pathways, necessitating sensitive and portable detection strategies for biomedical and point-of-care (POC) applications. In this work, we present a comparative study of two chemiluminescence (CL) methodologies on a miniaturized 3D-printed microfluidic chip: catalyst-assisted CL using cobalt chloride hexahydrate and electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL) at a graphite electrode. The cobalt-catalyzed CL method provided higher signal output about 85–90 a.u. with a linear range of 0.1–0.9mM, a limit of detection (LOD) of 0.0131mM (13 µM), and a limit of quantification LOQ of 0.043mM (43µM). In contrast, graphite electrode–based ECL achieved linear detection range 0.4–0.9mM, an LOD of 0. 036mM (36 µM) and an LOQ of 0.120mM (120 µM). The time analysis further revealed rapid emission and falloff kinetics, necessary for accurate quantification. The experimental results highlight the tradeoff between catalyst driven CL and electrogenerated ECL, offering valuable insights for the design of compact and reliable biosensing platforms.

records.paper_title: Design and Implement of Advanced Algorithm in MATLAB for Efficient Solar Dish Orientation
records.abstract: Precise determination of the Sun’s position in Line of Sight (LOS) is essential for applications including solar energy harvesting, satellite communications, and environmental monitoring. Accuracy in solar positioning enhances the efficiency of solar tracking systems, maximizes energy capture, and ensures reliable data transmission. In this work, a refined algorithm is developed by incorporating detailed orbital parameters into solar coordinate calculations. The computation is performed in MATLAB, and the same formulations are integrated into a Graphical User Interface (GUI) for user-friendly access. Our proposed algorithm demonstrates improved accuracy compared to simplified models reported in the literature, where only a limited set of parameters were used. Comparative analysis between the base algorithm and the refined model reveals significant error reduction. In particular, additional orbital parameters—mean anomaly (M), mean longitude (L₀), ecliptic longitude (λ), and obliquity of the ecliptic (ε) are introduced to enhance precision. Corrections for sidereal time and Julian date are also applied, thereby addressing variations due to Earth’s orbital and rotational dynamics. The improved computational approach, integrated into a MATLAB GUI, offers both high-accuracy solar tracking and accessibility for real-time applications where precise solar alignment is critical.

records.paper_title: Low-Cost AI-Driven Footfall Monitoring System with Enhanced Detection Range for Smart City Applications
records.abstract:
In recent times, demand for efficient football monitoring system has increased due to the rise of urbanization and necessity for resource management in public places. This Paper introduces a concise system that leverages dual IR sensors, LM358 comparator IC and IC 555 timer. The core functionality of the given system uses two strategically placed advanced IR sensors to count number of individuals entering and exiting the specific area to improve the detection accuracy and minimize error that may occur during the counting. Basic principle
of IR sensor is emitting and detecting IR light which allows it to capture movement in real time. This system is configured to extend the detection range from one foot to maximum ten foot. As it overcomes the limitations of restricted range, thus it will be capable to capture
accurate data in larger venues and can be represented as one of the possible low-cost solutions to use in smart city applications. With an accuracy of 90-95% and large distance coverage feature, this system addresses the most common challenge faced in footfall counting systems. Moreover, the data acquired is transmitted to cloud via ThingSpeak IoT platform enabling real time data analysis to make informed decisions over time.

co_author.name: Satyendra Kumar Singh
co_author.affiliation: Model Institute of Engineering and Technology (MIET), Jammu

records.paper_title: Design and Fabrication of Anthracite Coal-Derived Graphene Oxide Humidity Sensor for Moisture Sensing in Transformer Oil
records.abstract: Sensor-based moisture monitoring in transformer oil is needed for preserving transformer health and preventing failures. This work reports the development and response of a humidity sensor fabricated using Indian anthracite coal-derived graphene oxide (AC-GO) as the sensing material, a novel approach for moisture monitoring in transformer oil. AC-GO is synthesized using a one-pot technique. The screen-printed electrode (AgCl) is used to offer a highly conductive platform on a glass substrate for the fabrication of a sensor. The behavior of the sensor represents both capacitive and impedance response with respect to a change in relative humidity (%RH), allowing effective moisture detection. The sensor is tested in a transformer oil environment for moisture sensing across a wide range of frequencies and temperatures. Experimental results show that noticeable change in both capacitance and impedance as %RH levels and temperature changes, offering the sensor’s strong ability to monitor moisture accurately. The sensor’s response under varying %RH (5-90 %RH) and different transformer oil temperatures (20⁰C to 110⁰C) at different frequencies is thoroughly evaluated.

records.paper_title: Sustainable, Flexible and Ambient Temperature Operated Polyaniline-based  Chemiresistive Ammonia Sensor with Eco-Friendly Design
records.abstract: In this work, an eco-friendly, flexible and ambient temperature (~27 °C ± 2 °C) operated ammonia (NH3) sensor has been developed using electrospun polyaniline (PANI) fibers deposited on an eco-friendly paper substrate having printed graphene-carbon (G-C) interdigitated electrodes (IDEs). The sensor was designed to detect ammonia (NH₃) over a broad concentration range of 0.5 to 500 ppm, targeting applications in environmental and healthcare monitoring. Structural, elemental and morphological properties of the sensing layer were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), confirming the formation of well-aligned PANI fibers with entangled networks and rougher surface. The sensor exhibited excellent % response (1261 % at 500 ppm), reproducibility and good repeatability over multiple cycles. Selectivity studies showed a multifold % response towards ammonia gas as compared to interfering gases such as CO2, CO, SO2, and NO2. The use of paper as a low-cost, eco-friendly substrate, combined with the scalable fabrication route, highlights the potential of this work for sustainable and disposable ammonia sensing platforms and environmentally-friendly sensing solutions.

records.paper_title: AI-Driven Generation of Cortisol-Binding Peptides for Non-Invasive Stress Detection
records.abstract:
Cortisol is a primary biomarker of stress, released in sweat at concentrations that directly correlate with physiological stress levels. Detecting cortisol non-invasively offers significant potential for real-time stress monitoring and healthcare applications. Biosensors capable of binding cortisol can thus enable the development of novel diagnostic platforms for personalised health management. In our earlier work, a 38-mer peptide fragment derived from the protein 2V95 was identified as a functional binder to cortisol. In the present study, we applied generative artificial intelligence (AI) approaches to expand the sequence space and identify superior candidate peptides with improved binding affinity. By integrating sequence-based and structure-based AI models, we generated and screened a peptide library of nearly 10,000 sequences against cortisol, leading to the identification of high-affinity candidates for further evaluation.
Keywords—cortisol, biosensors, stress detection, generative AI, peptide design

records.paper_title: Multi-Command Control of Prosthetic Arm Using a Low-Cost EEG Blink Sequencer
records.abstract: We present a low-cost blink-based BCI using a Muse EEG headset that classifies blink sequences to enable real-time prosthetic arm control with 90.6% accuracy.

records.paper_title: Multi-Sensor Smart Insole System: Design, Fabrication and Evaluation for Real-Time Gait Analysis
records.abstract: Traditional gait analysis systems, such as optical motion capture and force plates, represent the gold standard in biomechanics but are prohibitively expensive, spatially confined to specialized laboratories, and require expert operation. These limitations restrict their utility for continuous, long-term moni toring in naturalistic environments, which is crucial for detecting intermittent pathologies and tracking rehabilitation progress. Addressing these challenges, this paper presents the comprehen sive design, implementation, and evaluation of SoleSync, a cost effective, multi-sensor smart insole system engineered for real time capture of plantar pressure distribution and gait dynamics. The system strategically integrates five force-sensing resistors (FSRs) distributed across key anatomical weight-bearing loca tions and a 6-axis inertial measurement unit (IMU) for kinematic context. A custom-designed, miniaturized printed circuit board (PCB) based on the STM32G070 microcontroller provides stable analog signal acquisition, noise-resistant sampling at up to 50 Hz, and reliable Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) communication. A dedicated cross-platform web application visualizes this data through real-time interpolated pressure heatmaps and 3D foot orientation rendering. Advanced sensor fusion algorithms extract critical gait events including heel strike and toe-off with high temporal precision. Comprehensive calibration methodologies for FSR characterization significantly improve measurement accuracy and inter-user repeatability. This work establishes a scalable, validated platform for wearable biomechanics research with significant applications in clinical gait analysis, athletic performance optimization, and remote patient monitoring.

records.paper_title: Wearable Fingertip PPG Compared to Wrist PPG for Emergency Alerting via Bluetooth or Cellular
records.abstract: Wearable fitness and biomedical devices are becoming increasingly popular for portable and real-time monitoring of vital signs for applications ranging from athletic performance to disease monitoring. Wearable devices, when combined with machine learning-derived algorithms to detect complex physiological responses, also have the potential to save lives through earlier prediction of emergencies such as opioid overdoses. We recommend that such devices use non-invasive sensing methods such as photoplethysmography (PPG) and pulse oximetry and be capable of alerting emergency services directly without the need for the user to possess a mobile phone. In this paper, we demonstrate a custom-built system with a microcontroller and PPG sensor with embedded software and firmware for reliable data acquisition from the fingertip. We compare this device with two other devices: 1) a similar custom-built device designed to obtain signals from the wrist; and 2) a commercially available cell phone compatible ring-type finger device. We compare measurements to ensure that data quality is sufficient to train machine learning algorithms. The custom devices support Bluetooth communication and existing emergency services alerting technology, yet are small enough to ensure comfort and wearability. The findings from this paper contribute to the body of knowledge in a large public health project that is building wearable devices for predicting and preventing accidental opioid overdoses.

records.paper_title: Graphene Based Flexible Piezoresistive Strain Sensor
records.abstract: Flexible and stretchable strain sensors are indis- pensable devices in several modern day applications including robotics and healthcare. Graphene based piezoresistive strain sensors are attractive as they combine the advantages of graphene and piezoresistive sensors such as high electrical conductivity, linearity and ease of fabrication among others. In the present work, a graphene nanoplatelets based piezoresistive strain sensor which also acts as a pressure sensor is fabricated and characterized. The strain sensor achieves a high gauge factor (22.29) implying good sensitivity to tensile strain and is found to be bendable and durable. COMSOL Multiphysics (version 6.0) simulation software has been used to evaluate the performance of the graphene piezoresistive strain sensor as a pressure sensor. The simulation of a linear relation between the force applied and the resistance of the sensor has been experimentally demonstrated by applying varying weights to the sensor. The practical demonstration of the pressure sensor paves way for future integration into engineering applications such as pressure monitoring in construction industry.

records.paper_title: Design of Wearable and Wireless Motion Capture System for Biomechanical application
records.abstract:
Motion capture is an essential biomechanical tool to analyze body part movements and to analyze gait using it. This usually involves fixed motion cameras focused on a particular area for recording movements.  This research was achieving kinematic analysis with complex motion capture using simple LED active markers and modest mobile. The video recorded via mobile camera was analyzed to visualize the dynamic angular changes of any joint graphically. With the help of active markers, video has been recorded and analyzed using MATLAB by manual allocation of joint markers. Further angle calculation was done using extracted coordinates of those markers which were finally displayed graphically, and the results were exported both vector-angle representation in the video as .mp4 and angle-frame data as .csv files. This shows the strong feasibility of using integrated mobile-MATLAB system for kinematic motion capture analysis. It has a significant implication in stability analysis of gait affected patients like in case of post-physiotherapy monitoring and other gait parameters like antalgic gait, propulsive gait, scissors gait and sports biomechanics like injury recovery biomechanics.
Keywords- kinematic analysis, markers, coordinates, gait.

records.paper_title: ACSRR–IDC Based Microwave Biosensor for Non-Invasive Creatinine Detection
records.abstract: Rapid detection of creatinine level is significant for the diagnosis of renal dysfunction. Conventional methods used for creatinine detection are not portable and cannot provide real-time results. This paper describes the design and validation of a microwave biosensor to overcome these limitations. The resonator is designed using a complementary split-ring resonator (CSRR) and an interdigitated capacitor (IDC) fabricated on a FR-4 substrate of dimensions 50×25 mm2. Simulations showed a resonance frequency of 2.013 GHz, while measurement results yielded a resonance of 1.941 GHz, with a deviation of 72 MHz. The fabricated device was tested with 10μL creatinine samples of 0.8 to 2.0 mg/dL, which are in the physiological range. A sensitivity of 0.77% is achieved for the detection of concentration change in chemical solutions. These results show the capability of the biosensor for real-time biomedical diagnosis.

records.paper_title: A LoRa-Based V2I System for Collision Warning at Blind-Turn
records.abstract:
To mitigate fatal collisions at non-line-of-sight (NLOS) blind curves, this paper presents the Blind Turn Accident
Alert System (BTAAS), a low-cost, solar-powered Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) solution utilizing sub-GHz LoRa. The
system uses intelligent nodes at curves to detect vehicles approaching from opposite directions via a motion-gated,
bidirectional logic and broadcasting real-time warnings of potential collision risks. Field validation demonstrated a reliable
link at a 150 m target distance (RSSI of -91.3 dBm) and robust operation at extended ranges with a negative SNR of -3
dB. Furthermore, an IMU-based Vector-Track algorithm effectively distinguishes between safe and converging trajectories.
Offering a 10× cost advantage over radar, estimated at Rs 3500 ($39) per roadside unit and Rs 1000 ($12) per vehicle
unit. BTAAS provides a validated, scalable technology for accident prevention in high-risk regions.

records.paper_title: A Multi-Modal Communication Framework for Enhanced Vehicular Coordination and Aerial Surveillance
records.abstract: This paper presents a multi-modal communication framework to improve vehicular coordination and aerial surveillance in urban environments. The proposed system integrates ground vehicles through 5G-V2X, edge cloud infrastructure, and drones to enable real-time tracking and reliable data exchange for high-priority transportation. We incorporate a channel model that addresses small-scale and large-scale fading effects, enhancing communication reliability in diverse, dynamic environments. Experimental evaluations validate the framework’s robustness and adaptability, demonstrating its potential for priority vehicle coordination, real-time traffic management, and other critical applications in smart cities.
